translated: The Collection of Long Sayings .
The Foul-Smelling
“The rice, the millet, the black gram,
The fruits of trees and fruits of vines,
Obtained by right means, they eat at night,
Not craving sensual pleasures, not speaking falsely.
When eating what is well-cooked, well-prepared,
Delicious food given by others,
Eating rice dishes,
You eat the foul-smelling, Kassapa.

analyzed: na āma gandhaḥ mama kappati iti
translated: “The foul-smelling is not suitable for me,”

analyzed: id ca iva tvam bhāsasi brahmabandhu  sālīnam annam paribhuñjamānaḥ
translated: Thus you speak, kinsman of Brahmā.🔽Eating rice dishes,
With well-prepared meat of birds,
I ask you about this, Kassapa:
How is the foul-smelling for you?”
“Killing living beings, cutting, binding,
Stealing, lying, and cheating,
Adultery, and visiting others’ wives,
This is the foul-smelling, not eating meat.

original: Ye idha kāmesu asaññatā janā,🔽Rasesu giddhā asucibhāvamassitā;
analyzed: ye idha kāmesu asaññatā janā  rasesu giddhā asuci bhāva massitā
translated: Those people here who are unrestrained in sensual pleasures,🔽Greedy for tastes, smeared with impurity,
Holding the view of annihilation, uneven, difficult to guide,

original: Esāmagandho na hi maṁsabhojanaṁ.🔽Ye lūkhasā dāruṇā piṭṭhimaṁsikā,
analyzed: na hi  ye lūkhasā dāruṇā piṭṭhi masikā
translated: The smell of meat is not the smell of food.🔽Those who are harsh, cruel, and deceitful,
Who betray friends, are merciless, and conceited,

analyzed: a dāna sīlāḥ na ca denti kassaci
translated: Who are stingy and never give to anyone,

original: Esāmagandho na hi maṁsabhojanaṁ.🔽Kodho mado thambho paccupaṭṭhāpanā,🔽Māyā usūyā bhassasamussayo ca;
analyzed: na hi  kodhaḥ madaḥ thambho paccupaṭṭhāpanā  māyā usūyā bhassa samussayaḥ ca
translated: The smell of meat is not the smell of food.🔽Anger, conceit, stubbornness, and arrogance,🔽Deception, envy, and flattery,

analyzed: māna atimānaḥ ca a sabbhi santhavaḥ
translated: Pride, excessive pride, and association with the ignoble,

original: Esāmagandho na hi maṁsabhojanaṁ.🔽Ye pāpasīlā iṇaghātasūcakā,🔽Vohārakūṭā idha pāṭirūpikā;
analyzed: na hi  ye pāpa sīlāḥ iṇa ghāta sūcakā  pāṭirūpikā
translated: The smell of meat is not the smell of food.🔽Those who are of bad character, who threaten and deceive,🔽Who cheat and defraud here with false weights,
The lowest of men who do evil here,
The smell of meat is not the smell of food.
Those people here who are undisciplined towards beings,
Who, taking from others, are intent on harming,
Immoral, greedy, harsh, and disrespectful,
The smell of meat is not the smell of food.

original: Etesu giddhā viruddhātipātino,🔽Niccuyyutā pecca tamaṁ vajanti ye;
analyzed: etesu giddhāḥ viruddha atipātinaḥ  niccuyyutā ped ca tamam vajanti ye
translated: Those who are greedy, opposed, and murderous,🔽Who are always intent on going to the darkness after death,
Beings fall headfirst into hell,
The smell of meat is not the smell of food.
Not being attached to fish and meat,
No shaven-headed ascetic, no one with matted hair,
No one with a topknot, no one who worships fire,

original: Ye vāpi loke amarā bahū tapā;🔽Mantāhutī yaññamutūpasevanā,
analyzed: ye vā api loke amarāḥ  manta āhutī yañña mutu upasevanā
translated: Or any of the many world-renouncers,🔽Or those who offer mantras, sacrifices, and seasonal offerings,

original: Sodhenti maccaṁ avitiṇṇakaṅkhaṁ.🔽Sotesu gutto viditindriyo care,
analyzed: sodhenti maccam a vitiṇṇa kaṅkha  sotesu guttaḥ care
translated: Can purify a mortal who has not crossed over doubt.🔽Guarding the ear faculty, with sense doors guarded,
Abiding in the Dhamma, delighting in honesty and gentleness,
Free from enmity, having given up all suffering,
The wise one is not smeared by what is seen or heard.”
Thus the Blessed One, again and again,
Explained this matter, and he understood, having mastered the mantras.
The sage proclaimed it with various verses,
Free from foul smell, unstained, difficult to fathom.
Having heard the Buddha’s well-spoken words,
Free from foul smell, dispelling all suffering,
With a humble mind, he paid homage to the Thus-Gone One,
And right there expressed his desire for the going forth.”
The Second Discourse on Foul Smell is finished.
